summary: This is the November 2020 executive summary of the Department of Justice Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) report investigating the conduct of federal prosecutors in the Southern District of Florida regarding the 2006-2008 criminal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein. The report examines the negotiation and execution of the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) and the office's interactions with victims, concluding that while the prosecutors did not commit professional misconduct, former U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta exercised poor judgment.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Multi-millionaire financier investigated for illegal sexual activity with minors. The NPA allowed him to plead guilty to state charges and avoid federal prosecution.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida
persons.context: The U.S. Attorney who approved the NPA with Epstein. He was the pivotal decision-maker and a subject of the OPR investigation. Later served as U.S. Secretary of Labor.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.role: U.S. Senator, Chairman of Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Oversight
persons.context: Sent a letter to OPR in December 2018 requesting an investigation into possible misconduct by DOJ attorneys following the Miami Herald report.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Nominated Acosta to be Secretary of Labor in 2017.

persons.name: Ron DeSantis
persons.context: Announced in August 2019 that he directed the Florida Department of Law Enforcement to open an investigation into state authorities' conduct relating to Epstein.

persons.name: Julie K. Brown
persons.context: Miami Herald reporter who authored the November 28, 2018 investigative report 'Perversion of Justice' that exposed the Epstein NPA and sparked public outrage.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, approved the Non-Prosecution Agreement that resolved the federal investigation into Epstein's crimes.
Epstein, through his team of prominent attorneys, negotiated the NPA with Acosta's office and later appealed to senior DOJ officials to invalidate it.
Senator Sasse requested the OPR investigation into the conduct of Acosta and other DOJ attorneys regarding the Epstein case.
President Trump nominated Acosta to be Secretary of Labor in 2017.

events.title: Initial Complaint to Palm Beach Police
events.description: Parents of a 14-year-old girl complained to Palm Beach Police that Epstein had paid her for a massage, initiating the local investigation.

events.title: State Grand Jury Indictment
events.description: A Palm Beach County grand jury indicted Epstein for felony solicitation of prostitution.

events.title: Draft Federal Indictment Prepared
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney submitted a draft 60-count federal indictment against Epstein to her supervisors.

events.title: Initial Offer to Epstein's Attorneys
events.description: The USAO offered to end its investigation if Epstein pled guilty to state charges, served jail time, registered as a sex offender, and provided a mechanism for victim damages.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: The NPA was signed, requiring Epstein to plead guilty to state charges and register as a sex offender, in exchange for the USAO ending its federal investigation and forgoing prosecution of Epstein and named co-conspirators.

events.title: Epstein's State Guilty Plea
events.description: Epstein appeared in state court and pled guilty to state charges of solicitation of prostitution and procurement of minors for prostitution, as required by the NPA. He was sentenced to 18 months incarceration.

events.title: CVRA Lawsuit Filed
events.description: A victim, 'Jane Doe,' filed an emergency petition in federal court alleging the government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by not consulting victims before the NPA.

events.title: Epstein Released from Custody
events.description: Epstein was released from custody after serving less than 13 months (with gain time) and began a term of home detention.

events.title: Miami Herald Investigation Published
events.description: Julie K. Brown's investigative report 'Perversion of Justice' was published, exposing the NPA and sparking public outrage and renewed scrutiny.

events.title: Court Finds CVRA Violation
events.description: The federal district court granted partial summary judgment to victims, ruling the government violated the CVRA by not consulting them about the NPA and misled them about the investigation's status.

events.title: SDNY Indicts Epstein
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York obtained a federal indictment charging Epstein with sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy.

events.title: Acosta Resigns as Labor Secretary
events.description: Acosta submitted his resignation as Secretary of Labor following continued controversy over his handling of the Epstein case.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Epstein was found hanging in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan and was pronounced dead. The medical examiner concluded suicide.

keyFacts: The OPR investigation concluded that the federal prosecutors, including former U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta, did not commit professional misconduct in negotiating the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein.

OPR found that Acosta exercised 'poor judgment' in approving the NPA, citing an over-expansive view of federalism, reliance on state officials over whom he had no authority, and agreeing to unusual terms without sufficient consideration.

The NPA required Epstein to plead guilty to state charges, serve jail time, register as a sex offender, and provide a mechanism for victim damages, while the USAO agreed to end its federal investigation and not prosecute Epstein or named co-conspirators.

Victims were not informed of or consulted about the NPA before it was signed, and post-NPA communications from the FBI risked misleading them about the investigation's status, leading to a federal court finding of CVRA violations.

The report details Epstein's efforts after the NPA was signed to invalidate it by appealing to senior DOJ officials, arguing the matter was a 'quintessentially state matter,' an appeal which was ultimately rejected in June 2008.
